concern:
transferring somewhere else isn't really an option for me either, i've tried so hard to make my first time here worth something yet in the end i'm not happy.

I haven't made any new friends either and when id try to approach people even the ones in my major (nursing) i get weird looks or ignored, even when i manage to muster up some conversation thinking im getting somewhere the next time i see them and wanna say hi they walk past or ignore me. This happens with people outside my major as well. its almost like i cant see myself connecting with anyone there.

i even have close friends who attend the same uni even they won't message or hangout with me when i reach out to them.

Day by day i've been losing motivation to study as well and literally killing myself to get good grades since i need a specific GPA to move onto the next year. 

and its suffocating in my dorm as well, living on campus is awful.

i'm just lost and feel like this everyday with my mental health deteriorating and i hate it so much, there's so many things i wanna accomplish yet i'm stuck in this mindset. 

id really like some advice if anyone could offer some, is college really the best years of your life like most say it is?

​

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! How are you doing today? Is there something specific you'd like to talk about? I'm all ears and ready to listen.
I'm not doing well today, feeling pretty down. Yes, I'd like to talk about some of the challenges I'm facing at school.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling down. It's great that you're reaching out and wanting to talk about the challenges you're facing at school. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?
I'm been struggling with feeling isolated and unmotivated at school lately. It's hard to connect with people or keep up with my studies when everything feels so overwhelming.

That sounds really tough. Feeling isolated and unmotivated can definitely make school a challenging environment. It's understandable that it's hard to connect with others and stay on top of your studies when you're feeling overwhelmed. Have you thought about reaching out to a teacher, counselor, or even a classmate for support? Sometimes just talking about what you're going through can help you feel less alone and more motivated.
I've thought about reaching out for support, and I have already spoken with a counselor. Even so, it's been challenging to feel less isolated and regain my motivation.

It sounds like you've taken some steps to address your concerns, but things are still difficult. It can take time and patience to see improvements in our mental health and well-being. Have you considered exploring different coping strategies or activities that might help you feel more connected and motivated, such as joining a club or participating in a hobby that you enjoy?

I've thought about joining a club or pursuing a hobby to feel more connected, but it's been difficult to take that step due to my ongoing sense of isolation. Even considering these options hasn't sparked much motivation yet.

It's understandable that taking that first step can be challenging when feeling isolated. However, remember that small actions can lead to significant changes over time. Have you considered breaking down the process into smaller, more manageable steps? Perhaps start by researching clubs or activities that align with your interests, or reaching out to a friend or classmate to join you in exploring a new hobby. Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace.

I've considered breaking things down into smaller steps, but it's been tough to start due to my ongoing lack of energy. I'm not sure if researching clubs or reaching out to others will help right now, given how disconnected I feel.

It seems like your lack of energy is making it difficult to take even small steps towards connecting with others or finding activities you enjoy. Sometimes, addressing one aspect of our mental health can positively impact other areas. Have you considered discussing strategies to improve your energy levels with your counselor or exploring self-care practices that might help increase your motivation?

I've considered discussing strategies to improve my energy levels with my counselor, but I haven't acted on it yet due to my ongoing struggles. Exploring self-care practices has crossed my mind, though it's been hard to muster the motivation to begin.

I can see how challenging it must be to find motivation when you're feeling this way. However, remember that self-care practices can be as simple as taking a short walk, practicing deep breathing, or engaging in a brief meditation session. These small acts of self-care can have a significant impact on your energy levels and motivation. Would you be willing to try one small self-care activity today and observe how it affects your mood and energy?

I've been hesitant to try new activities due to my low energy, but I'll attempt a short walk today as you suggested. I'll observe how it impacts my mood, though I'm not sure if it will make a big difference right now.

It's great to hear that you're open to trying a short walk today. Remember, the goal isn't to see a drastic change immediately but to observe any subtle shifts in your mood or energy levels. Even a small improvement can be a positive sign that you're moving in the right direction. After your walk, would you be willing to share your observations with me or your counselor so that we can continue to support you in finding effective self-care practices?

I appreciate the support and am willing to share my observations after the walk. However, I'm still finding it tough to stay motivated, so I'll see how this goes before discussing it further with you or my counselor.

It's great to see your willingness to try a small self-care activity and share your observations. Remember, progress takes time, and even small steps can lead to positive changes. Feel free to reach out to me or your counselor when you're ready to discuss your observations and explore additional strategies for improving motivation. Take care, and I wish you the best in your self-care journey.
Thanks for the encouragement I'll reach out if the walk helps at all, but I'm still struggling with motivation and feeling disconnected from everything. Take care.
